title-group.article-title: Quantitative Analysis of Cellular Proliferation and Differentiation of the Human Seminiferous Epithelium In Vitro

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Microscopy, Laboratory of Cell Biology, UMIB, Institute of Biomedical Sciences Abel Salazar (ICBAS), University of Porto, Porto, Portugal
2Centre for Reproductive Genetics Prof. Alberto Barros (CGR-ABarros), Porto, Portugal
3Department of Microscopy, Laboratory of Cytogenetics, Institute of Biomedical Sciences Abel Salazar (ICBAS), University of Porto, Porto, Portugal
4Department of Genetics, Faculty of Medicine, University of Porto (FMUP), Alameda Prof. Hernâni Monteiro, Porto, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: Mário Sousa, Department of Microscopy, Laboratory of Cell Biology, Biomedical Research Multidisciplinary Unit (UMIB), Institute of Biomedical Sciences Abel Salazar (ICBAS), University of Porto, Rua Jorge Viterbo Ferreira 228, Building 1, Floor 2 Room 10.2.3, 4050-313 Porto, Portugal Email: msousa@icbas.up.pt

abstract.p: The aim of the present work was to quantitate the temporal and stage-specific effects of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and testosterone on the proliferation and differentiation capacities of the human seminiferous epithelium. Seminiferous tubule fragments were kept in culture for 28 days and 5-bromo-2’-deoxyuridine incorporation was used to determine cell proliferation. Data demonstrated a gradual loss of germ cells during the culture period, no decrease in Sertoli cell numbers, and maintenance of the general architecture of the seminiferous tubules. Both FSH and testosterone increased germ cell survival, spermatogonia proliferation, and germ cell differentiation, especially during the first week of culture. At the end of the first week, differentiation of spermatocytes was observed, especially when 50 IU/L FSH and 1 µmol/L testosterone were used. In conclusion, using this methodology, it was possible to quantify germ cell proliferation and differentiation, in a reproducible way, with results compatible with the timing of human spermatogenesis in vivo.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Spermatogenesis is a hormone-dependent process. Hormones are critical for the regulation and development of germ cells, as well as the functioning of somatic cells. In the testicle, follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) is critical in the beginning of spermatogenesis, and both FSH and testosterone (T) are necessary for the differentiation of germ cells. 1
–6 Follicle-stimulating hormone directly activates the transcription for nutrients, hormones, and growth and paracrine factors in Sertoli cells (SC), which are essential for spermatogenesis. 6,7 Follicle-stimulating hormone also inhibits apoptosis and stimulates cell cycle and meiosis. 1 –3,6 The functions of T are similar to those of FSH, besides being fundamental in spermiogenesis. 2,3,6 Both FSH and T regulate spermiogenesis synergistically in early (flagellum extrusion) and mid-spermiogenesis (elongating) and have an antagonist action in late (elongated) and terminal spermiogenesis. 4,5 Culture of isolated (micromethod) diploid germ cells (spermatogonia and primary spermatocytes) with FSH and T resulted in stable chromosome composition and gene expression, inhibition of apoptosis through the extrinsic pathway, and induced proliferation, meiosis, and differentiation. 4,5

Obtaining an effective method for studying spermatogenesis in vitro would be essential for analyzing proliferation, meiosis, and cellular differentiation. In addition, it would provide a useful tool for toxic and infectious studies. Ultimately, the method would offer the possibility of therapeutical purposes. 2,4,5,8
–13

The aim of the present work was to quantitatively study the proliferation and differentiation of human spermatogenic cells during the long-term culture of human seminiferous tubules (ST) from patients with complete spermatogenesis using 5-bromo-2’-deoxyuridine (BrdU; Sigma, Saint Louis, USA) for the detection of proliferative cells and evaluate the temporal and stage-specific effects of FSH and T on the proliferation and differentiation capacities of the human seminiferous epithelium.

sec.title: Biological Material
sec.p: According to the National Law on Medically Assisted Procreation (PMA, Law 32/2006) and the National Council on Medically Assisted Procreation (CNPMA, 2008) guidelines, human ST fragments were obtained, after patients’ informed and written consent. In our center, the only available cases with complete spermatogenesis (albeit not considered normal) are hypospermatogenesis. Four cases were selected, with a mean age of 31 years (28-35), that for intracytoplasmic sperm injection treatment cycles at treatment open testicular biopsy had abundant germ cells and frequent in situ mobile spermatozoa. Patients had normal serum FSH levels, testicular volume, epididymis, vas deferens, and karyotypes but showed absence of Y chromosome microdeletions and cystic fibrosis mutations. Patients also presented homogeneity for the infertility causes, demographic data, and clinical evaluation.

sec.title: Organotypic Culture of Human Testis Explants
sec.p: Per patient, ten 2-mm3 fragments of ST were collected from multiple sites of both testes and immediately transferred onto the culture medium sperm preparation medium with Hepes buffer (SPM-HEPES); Medicult, Copenhagen, Denmark) in tissue culture plates Falcon (Falcon, Becton Dickinson, Franklin Lakes, New Jersey). After cutting (20 fragments of 1 mm3 each), using surgical blades, they were incubated in 1 mL of SPM at 32°C, 5% CO2, in plastic conic graduated tubes (Nunc, Roskild, Denmark; tissue fragments were simply submerged in the media inside the tubes). Experiments were carried out in 3 different culture media: (1) SPM (control); (2) SPM supplemented with 50 IU/L rFSH (human recombinant FSH; Gonal-F, folitropin 2, Orgalutran; Organon, Oss, Netherlands) and 1 µmol/L T (water-soluble T, 50/1; Sigma, Barcelone, Spain); and (3) SPM with 500 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L T (500/10). Cultures were evaluated at 4 different days (0, 7, 14, and 28) for controls and 3 days (7, 14, and 28) for experiments with hormones. The 50/1 concentration was shown to be sufficient to produce the maximal effect on in vitro maturation of germ cells in men with normal spermatogenesis, but pharmacological concentrations of 500/10 were needed to improve the results. 14,15 To avoid anoxic culture conditions, we used very small testicular fragments, with frequent mixing (15 minutes) and media changes (every 48 hours) and cultured at 32°C. Fragments also contained a small portion of interstitial tissue, which together with the presence of SC in the seminiferous epithelium was expected to help maintain cell interactions and support. The interstitial tissue was not analyzed in the present study.

sec.title: Analysis of Cell Replication
sec.p: Cellular proliferation was measured by means of a BrdU (Sigma) solution at 10 mmol/L in SPM. Three tubes with the BrdU solution were prepared. One tube without hormones, the second with 50 IU/L rFSH and 1 µmol/L T, and the third with 500 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L T. One milliliter of the solution without hormones was added to each of the 4 control tubes (for days 0, 7, 14, and 28). One milliliter of the solution with hormones was then added to each of the 6 tubes (3 tubes for 50/1 and 3 tubes for 500/10) of hormonal experiments (for days 7, 14, and 18). The 10 tubes were then incubated at 32°C with 5% CO2 for 30 minutes. 2 During this period, the fragments of the testicular biopsy were prepared. Two fragments of 1 mm2 each were then placed in each tube and incubated in culture medium with BrdU during 18 hours. In all cases, the tubes were properly labeled and coated with silver paper to avoid any light exposure. After that time, fragments were washed with SPM to totally eliminate BrdU. Tubes were periodically agitated during the day (every 15 minutes) and media changed every 2 days until the end of the experiment. On days 0, 7, 14, and 28, the corresponding fragments were removed and added to the fixative.

sec.title: Light Microscopy
sec.p: Fragments of ST were fixed overnight (4°C) in Bouin (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany), washed with 70% ethanol (Merck), dehydrated using an increasing sequence of ethanol, cleared with xylene (Merck), and impregnated and embedded in paraffin (Merck). Glass slides (Industrial Quality, Germany) were coated with Vectabond Reagent Solution (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, California). Ten sequential sections (3 µm thick) were obtained from each block, and the first was stained with hematoxylin (Vector Laboratories) to verify the integrity and the amount of ST. For analysis, each section should contain at least 20 ST. The mean number of ST counted was 36.5 at day 0, 22.5 at day 7, 23 at day 14, and 22.5 at day 28. The total number of ST in each section was counted and the total number of cells in each seminiferous tubule was registered. That is, at different times different ST were counted, and the number of ST did not change at different times or places.

sec.title: Immunostaining
sec.p: Imunohistochemistry was performed with Streptavidin–Biotin and Vectastain universal quick kit detection system (Vector Laboratories). Sections were dewaxed and rehydrated, slides placed in a dark, moistened chamber, incubated (5 minutes, at room temperature [RT]) with 3% hydrogen peroxide (Merck) to block endogenous peroxidases, washed (5 minutes) in distilled water, incubated (10 minutes, RT) with 1 mol/L hydrochloric acid (Sigma) to denature DNA, washed (5 minutes), treated (5 minutes, RT) with 0.01% Trypsin–porcine pancreas trypsin (PBS: Sigma; phosphate buffered saline [PBS]: Biochrom AG Instamed, Berlin, Germany), washed (5 minutes) with distilled water and then PBS. Sections were then incubated (10 minutes, RT) with horse serum (Blocking Solution; Vector Laboratories) to block nonspecific reactive locals, drained, and incubated (15 minutes) with Avidin (Vector) followed (15 minutes) by Biotin (Vector). Thereafter, sections were washed (5 minutes, PBS), incubated (1 hour, 37°C) with a primary monoclonal antibody anti-BrdU (Clone BU33, Immunohistology Grade; Sigma), at 1:200, containing 1.5% Blocking Serum, washed (5 minutes, PBS), incubated (10 minutes, RT) with the universal biotinylated secondary antibody (Vector Laboratories), washed (5 minutes, PBS), incubated (5 minutes, RT) with Streptavidin–Peroxidase (Vector Laboratories), washed (5 minutes, PBS), labeled with the chromogen 3,3’diaminobenzidine (DAB Substract kit; Vector Laboratories), washed (5 minutes), contrasted with hematoxylin and washed and embedded in Entellan (Merck). As a negative control, incubation with the primary antibody was omitted.

sec.title: Quantification of Cell Number
sec.p: Sections were observed under an optic microscope (Leica DMRBE; Schmidheiny, Switzerland) attached to Leica DFC 480 camera and a digital imaging system (Leica IM50; Schmidheiny) installed in a desktop computer (Intel Pentium 4, Microsoft Windows XP Professional). All cells present in a field were counted. The total number of ST in each section was counted and the total number of positive and negative cells in each ST was registered, according to the following cellular types: Sertoli cells (SC), spermatogonia A dark (Ad), spermatogonia A pale (Ap), spermatogonia B (SGB), primary spermatocytes at leptotene (Lep), primary spermatocytes at zygotene (Zyg), primary spermatocytes at pachytene (Pac), secondary spermatocytes (ST2), round spermatids (Sa), and elongated spermatids (Sd). For quantification purposes, it was difficult to differentiate SGB from Lep and Zyg from Pac, and thus these were aggregated (SGB-Lep; Zyg-Pac).

Cells of the human ST were identified as previously described (Figure 1). 4,5,16–23 In the normal human seminiferous epithelium, each section usually does not show all germ cell types, with some sections show a predominance of a cell type. Cells were recognized by position, shape, and size as well as by nuclear morphology (size, nucleolus, and chromatin appearance). Cell recognition was performed by an experienced observer (M. S.). Cells were evaluated regardless of the stage of the cycle of the SE.

caption.p: General morphology of the seminiferous epithelium (A, B). Sertoli cells (SC) are elongated with the base inserted on the basal lamina (BL). The nucleus is elongated, indented, has short coarse granules/cords of heterochromatin and a prominent nucleolus and is generally above the spermatogonia line. Spermatogonia A-dark (Ad) are inserted on the BL and have an ovoid nucleus, with peripheral thick heterochromatin and a pale area in the middle. Spermatogonia A-pale (Ap) are inserted on the BL and have an ovoid nucleus, with fine fibrilar chromatin. Leptotene primary spermatocytes (L) have a spherical nucleus, with fine dense heterochromatin straight cords, forming a clew all over the nucleus. They are smaller than spermatogonia A and are generally above the spermatogonia line. They were counted together with spermatogonia B. Pachytene primary spermatocytes (P) have a large spherical nucleus, with short coarse chromatin cords and are generally above the spermatogonia line. They were counted together with Zyg. They are about 19 to 24 µm in diameter. Round spermatids (Sa) have a small round nucleus, with pale chromatin and a large pale acrosomal vesicle. In sections, the chromatin appears densely stained by hematoxylin. They are about 8 to 10 µm in diameter. Elongated spermatids (Sd) have an elongated dense nucleus and a short basal pale cytoplasm. Peritubular cells (PTCs). Paraffin sections. Hematoxylin-Eosin. (A, B).

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Statistical analysis was carried out through the SPSS program for Windows (version 16). For each of the above-mentioned cellular types, the total amount of cells and the amount of BrdU-positive per 1000 SC were calculated. This analysis was undertaken for each patient and then the average and the pattern deviation (standard deviation [SD]) of the 4 cases were calculated. After descriptive analysis, a nonparametric Mann-Whitney U test was used to compare each of the cellular types along the 28 days and verify the effect of hormonal supplementation. A value of P < .05 was considered to be statistically significant for both testes.

sec.title: Morphologic Analysis
sec.p: As viewed under the light microscope, along the 28 days of culture, the germ cell number gradually decreased. During this period, the general morphology of the ST fragments retained the critical features such as overall structural integrity and the seminiferous epithelium cells, which decreased in number (Figures 2 and 3)

caption.p: General morphological architecture of testicular fragments containing the seminiferous tubules and interstitial tissues, at days 0, 7, 14, and 28, in control (C) and hormonal experiments 50 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone (50/1), and 500 IU/L rFSH /10 µmol/L testosterone (500/10). Note the progressive loss of cells along the culture period. Bouin fixation. Paraffin sections. Hematoxylin-Eosin. Bars = 200 µm (A), 40 µm (B, J), 100 µm (C-H), 20 µm (I, K), and 10 µm (L). rFSH indicates human recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone.

High magnification of the seminiferous tubules, at days 14 and 28, in hormonal experiments 50 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone (50/1), and 500 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone (500/10). Note the progressive loss of cells along the culture period. Bouin fixation. Paraffin sections. Hematoxylin-Eosin. Bars = 35 µm (A-D). rFSH indicates human recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone.

sec.title: Quantification of Cell Number
sec.p: For SC (Figure 4), although no significant differences in the total mean cell number were found during culture days 0, 7, 14, and 28 or among the hormonal experimental groups (control, 50/1, 500/10), the 500/10 gave the best cell number preservation. As the mean number of SC was maintained all along the culture period, independently of hormonal supplementation, the mean number of germ cell was calculated per 1000 SC. 24

caption.p: Comparisons of the mean number per 1000/SC of round spermatids (Sa) and elongated spermatids (Sd), at days of culture 0, 7, 14, and 28, in control experiments (without hormone supplementation; continuous line), and hormonal experiments 50 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone (discontinued line) and 500 IU/L rFSH /10 µmol/L testosterone (dotted line). Statistically significant differences (P < .05) within (lower cases) and between (upper cases) experiments are identified by changes in the representative letters. SD is not presented due to the high values that would fill and hide the lines (see Support Information Tables-Graphs).

sec.p: For spermatogonia (Figure 4), in controls, Ad exhibited a significant decrease in the mean cell number along the culture period, whereas for Ap and total spermatogonia A, Ap, and Ad (SGA), there was a period of stabilization (in the mean cell number) during the second week. In hormonal experiments, for Ad, Ap, and total spermatogonia A, there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number after day 7, stabilizing after day 14. Comparisons between groups showed that the mean number of cells in controls was significantly lower, except at day 14 for Ap, and at day 14 regarding 50/1 for Ad and total SGA. There were no significant differences between the 2 hormonal groups.

For SGB /Lep (Figure 4), in the control group there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number along the culture period. In hormonal group 50/1, there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number after day 7, stabilizing after day 14. For group 500/10, there was a significant decrease in SGB-Lep after day 7, with a recover during the third week of culture. Comparisons between groups showed significant lower mean number of cells in controls except at day 14. No significant differences were found between hormonal groups 50/1 and 500/10 along the culture days. For Zyg/Pac (Figure 4), in the control group there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number along the culture days, with a period of stabilization during the second week. In the hormonal groups, there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number after day 7. Comparisons between groups revealed significant lower mean cell numbers in the control group, except at day 14 with respect to the hormonal group 500/10. A significant lower mean cell number was found at day 14 for group 500/10 in relation to group 50/1.

For Sa (Figure 5), in the control group there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number, stabilizing between days 7 and 14. In hormonal group 50/1, there was a stable mean cell number during 14 days of culture, with a significant decrease after day 14. In group 500/10, there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number, stabilizing between days 7 and 14. Comparisons between groups revealed significant lower mean cell numbers in controls and in group 500/10 regarding group 50/1. For Sd (Figure 5), in control and 500/10 hormonal groups, there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number, stabilizing after day 7. In group 50/1, there was no significant changes in the mean cell number along the culture period. Comparisons between groups revealed significant lower mean cell numbers in controls and in group 500/10 than group 50/1.

caption.p: Seminiferous epithelium. BrdU incorporation and detection (arrows): basal lamina (BL); peritubular cells (PTCs); Sertoli cells (SC); spermatogonia A-pale (Ap: arrow in A); spermatogonia A-dark (Ad: arrow in B); spermatogonia B/leptotene (L: arrows in C); zygotene/ pachytene (P: arrows in D). Round spermatids (Sa); elongated spermatids (Sd). (A, B): images taken from controls at day 0 after BrdU incorporation; (C): image taken from hormonal experiments 50 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone at day 7 after BrdU incorporation; (D): image taken from hormonal experiments 500 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone at day 7 after BrdU incorporation. Bouin fixation. Paraffin sections. rFSH indicates human recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone; BrdU, 5-bromo-2′-deoxyuridine.

sec.title: Analysis of Cell Division and Differentiation
sec.p: For BrdU-positive spermatogonia Ad (Figures 6 and 7), in the control group there was a significant decrease in the mean number of Ad-positive cells after day 7. In hormonal 50/1 experimental group, there were no significant changes along the culture period, with values lower than controls. In group 500/10, there was a significant increase at day 7, followed by a significant decrease, stabilizing after day 14. Comparisons between groups showed no differences, except at day 14, where hormonal groups had significant lower Ad-positive cells in relation to control. No significant differences were found between hormonal groups along the culture days. For BrdU-positive Ap and BrdU-positive total SGA cells (Figures 6 and 7), in controls there was a significant decrease in the mean cell number of proliferative cells, with no differences between days 7 and 14. In the hormonal groups, there were a significant decrease after day 7, stabilizing after day 14. Comparisons between groups revealed significant lower Ap- and total SGA-positive cells in controls, except at days 14 and 28 in 50/1 group. No significant differences were found between 50/1 and 500/10 groups along the culture days.

caption.p: Comparisons of the mean number of Sertoli cells (SC) and of the mean number per 1000/SC of dark spermatogonia (SGA dark), pale spermatogonia (SGA Pale), total spermatogonia A (dark and pale: SGA), B spermatogonia and leptotene primary spermatocytes (SGB-Lep) and primary spermatocytes at zygotene and pachytene (Zig-Pac), at days of culture 0, 7, 14, and 28, in control experiments (without hormone supplementation; continuous line) and hormonal experiments 50 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone (discontinued line) and 500 IU/L rFSH /10 µmol/L testosterone (dotted line). Statistically significant differences (P < .05) within (lower cases) and between (upper cases) experiments are identified by changes in the representative letters. SD is not presented due to the high values that would fill and hide the lines (see Support Information Tables-Graphs).

Comparisons of the mean number per 1000/SC of BrdU-positive dark spermatogonia (SGA Dark), pale spermatogonia (SGA pale), total spermatogonia A (dark and pale: SGA), B spermatogonia and leptotene primary spermatocytes (SGB-Lep) and primary spermatocytes at zygotene and pachytene (Zig-Pac) at days of culture 0, 7, 14, and 28, in control experiments (without hormone supplementation; continuous line) and hormonal experiments 50 IU/L rFSH and 10 µmol/L testosterone (discontinued line) and 500 IU/L rFSH /10 µmol/L testosterone (dotted line). Statistically significant differences (P < .05) within (lower cases) and between (upper cases) experiments are identified by changes in the representative letters. SD is not presented due to the high values that would fill and hide the lines (see Support Information Tables-Graphs).

sec.p: For BrdU-positive SGB /Lep cells (Figures 6 and 7) in control and hormone groups, there was a significant decrease in the mean number of SGB-Lep-positive cells after day 7, except between days 14 and 28 for 500/10 group. Comparisons between groups revealed significant lower positive cells at days 7 and 28 in controls. No significant differences were found between 50/1 and 500/10 hormonal groups. For BrdU-positive Zyg/Pac cells (Figures 6 and 7), there was a significant increase in the mean number of proliferative Zyg-Pac cells up to day 14 in controls and up to day 7 in 50/1 and 500/10 hormone experimental groups, followed by a significant decrease. Comparisons between groups revealed, in controls, significant lower positive cells at days 7 and 28 in the 50/1 group. At day 7, the 50/1 group presented significant higher positive cells compared to the 500/10 group.

Hormone supplementation improved cell proliferation and differentiation, with decreased cell numbers occurring only after 1 week of culture but stabilizing after day 14. The number of round spermatids decreased only after day 14, and the mean cell number of Sd increased without loss during all the culture periods, both under hormone 50/1 stimulation. At the end of culture, the mean number of germ cells under hormone supplementation was always higher than controls, except for Ad.

Comparisons between the 2 hormone groups showed that 50/1 gave better results with reference to the total numbers of germ cells except for SGB-Lep. Concerning BrdU-positive germ cells, the 50/1 concentration gave better results for Ap, total SGA and Zyg-Pac, and 500/10 for Ad and SGB-Lep.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Sertoli cells provide support, nutrients, and regulatory factors to germ cells, mainly through FSH and T stimulation, which are the main hormones regulating spermatogenesis. 1,3,7,25
–30 In men, spermatogonia Ad are considered the stem cell that functions as a regenerative reserve, displaying low mitotic activity. On the other hand, spermatogonia Ap and SGB are recognized as the progenitor cells of the male germ line. 16,17,28
–32

The development of an effective culture system for human testis explants is important, as it can lead to the unveiling of new therapies for men having infertility, particularly those treated with chemotherapy or radiotherapy. Besides clinical applications, an effective culture system is also relevant for basic research to enable investigation into the influence of several factors on testicular function. 2,6,9
–13,33 .

In the human, the estimated cycle time in vivo to attain the pachytene stage is about 16 days. 17,31 The same duration time, using autoradiography, was obtained using human organ cultures, with differentiation into pachytene taking about 2 weeks. Although SC and germ cells remained alive for 3 weeks, the haploid germ cells progressively degenerated. 8,34

Hormones are essential to support human ST organ and cell cultures, as FSH 35 and T 36 appear essential to inhibit apoptosis, 5,37 –39 and stimulate spermatogonia proliferation, meiosis, and spermiogenesis, 4,5,14,15,21,34,37,40 –42 although the involvement of gonadotrophins and T in human ST and germ cell cultures were not observed in some cases. 24,43

Previous quantification of proliferation and differentiation in human testes explants with BrdU 24 used a specified medium supplemented with 200 ng/mL FSH, 1 IU/mL human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), and 10% fetal calf serum (FCS). Fragments were incubated for 16 days at 34°C in a 5% CO2, with change in media every 2 days. To avoid anoxic culture conditions, small testis fragments of 3 mm3 (to avoid necrosis) were used. Two fragments were placed in each well of a 6-well plate with 2 mL of the medium. Because HCG could not have penetrated the tissue, 5 IU/mL HCG was added to culture in test tubes, but the results were the same. We performed the same method, using smaller fragments (2 mm3) in test tubes, with FSH and T, at 2 different concentrations, for 28 days, without FCS supplementation. Organ culture was used to conserve germ cell and SC interactions as well as to contain a small portion of the interstitial compartment. As discussed in the above-mentioned study, 24 the germ cell types and SC were identified based on the morphological criteria (all cells in a field were counted but not using measurements of cell diameters with the Cast software from Olympus used by the authors) and also the number of germ cells were counted per 1000 SC.

For analyzing cell proliferation and differentiation using BrdU, authors 24 performed the following experiments: (a) explants were incubated for 1 hour to study the germ cells in S-phase at the beginning of the culture (day 0); (b) explants were incubated for 5 hours and then further cultured for 1 week to study germ cell survival and differentiation; and (c) after 1 week of culture, explants were incubated for 5 hours and again cultured for 1 week. Only spermatogonia and pre-Lep were BrdU positive at the beginning of the culture. After 1 week, pre-Lep were differentiated into pachytene spermatocytes. Germ cells kept replicating and differentiating between 1 and 2 weeks of culture, which is compatible with the timing of human spermatogenesis in vivo (7-14 days). We used an incubation period of 18 hours, followed by culture of explants for 28 days. The same results were obtained.

In the present study, the presence of BrdU-labeled germ cells demonstrated that germ cells replicated and differentiated along the entire culture period of 28 days. On day 0, after 18 hours of initial exposure to BrdU, the large majority of positive germ cells were spermatogonia Ap (about 183 Ap/1000 SC) and SGB /Lep (about 177 Lep/1000 SC). As expected, the proliferation rate of spermatogonia Ad was low, but it improved significantly under a high hormone supplementation of FSH and T (500/10). These results are comparable to the analysis in Rhesus monkeys, in which only <1% of Ad cells were positive. 29,30

The observed proliferation rates of total spermatogonia A and SGB-Lep were maximal during the first week of culture in the presence of hormones (from 96 total BrdU-positive SGA cells in controls to 189 positive cells per 1000 SC). After the first week, the observed decrease in cell proliferation followed the decrease in total SGA cell numbers in culture. Compared with the control group, total SGA proliferation at day 28 was still substantially higher in the 50/1 hormone treated group and for both hormone concentrations regarding total SGA and SGB/Lep proliferation, suggesting that the presence of hormones enabled germ cells to sustain proliferation for long periods of time.

The observed differentiation of Zyg/Pac occurred at the end of the first week. This process was accelerated in cells treated with media supplemented with hormones. In untreated cells, the maximum differentiation of Zyg/Pac occurred at the end of the second week of culture (about 151 Zyg-Pac BrdU-positive cells/1000 SC), whereas in treated cells the maximum differentiation occurred at day 7 (about 352 Zyg-Pac BrdU-positive cells/1000 SC), indicating an acceleration of the differentiation due to hormonal supplementation, especially with the 50/1 hormone concentration. These results are similar with the timing of human spermatogenesis in vivo, during which pre-Lep differentiated into pachytene within 7 to 14 days. 16 In relation to the control group, Zyg/Pac differentiation at day 28 was still substantially higher in the 50/1 hormone treated group, suggesting that the presence of hormones enabled germ cells to sustain differentiation for long periods of time.

Media supplemented with 50 IU/L FSH and 1 µmol/L T was more powerful for Ap, total SGA, and Zyg-Pac, whereas media supplemented with 500 U/L FSH and 10 µmol/L T appeared to be more effective for Ad and SGB-Lep.

In conclusion, the present culture system allowed maintaining human ST in culture for a month without any significant loss of SC, maintaining the integrity of the ST and the interstitial compartment in the presence of all germ cell types (although with a decease in cell number). All germ cells were able to maintain proliferative (Ap, SGB/Lep) and differentiation (Zyg/Pac) capacities until the end of the culture (28 days), except Ad. This culture system also enabled to quantitate human spermatogenesis using a reproducible method that detects cellular proliferation, with differentiation times compatible with the timing of human spermatogenesis in vivo. 16,17,22,31 Although the present model is still unsuitable for therapeutic purposes, 2 it is a valuable tool for basic research as well as for pharmacology and toxicology studies. 24 Additional supplementation of media may prove in the immediate future the efficiency of the present system.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors acknowledge Mariana Cunha and Paulo Viana, BSc, Clinical Embryologists-ESHRE (biopsy preparation), CGR-ABarros; Luis Ferraz, MD, Urologist (Andrology patient evaluation and testicular biopsies), Director, Department of Urology, Hospital Centre of Vila Nova de Gaia; Elsa Oliveira, 1st Class Technical Specialist of Pathology, Cytology and Thanatology in the Area of Diagnosis and Therapy (microscopy assistance) and Milaydis Sosa Napolskij, BSc (English translation), ICBAS-UP. This study was supported in part by Foundation for Science and Technology (FCT), with a PhD grant to Rosália Sá (SFRH/BD/23616/2005).

fn.label: Authors’ Note
fn.p: The experimental part of this work was performed at CGR-ABarros and Department of Microscopy, Laboratory of Cell Biology, ICBAS-UP. We here state that the material contained in the submitted manuscript has not been published previously and has not being submitted elsewhere for publication. We declare that we all participated in the present study and that we have seen and approved the final version. We also declare that if this publication is accepted, it will not be published elsewhere including electronically in the same form, in English, or in any other language, without the written consent of the copyright holder. Ethical guidelines were followed in the conduct of research, with written informed consent of all patients having been obtained before the beginning of the present work. This work did not involve human or animal experiments. Patient database were only used with a statistical purpose. According to the National Law on Medically Assisted Procreation (PMA, Law 32/2006) and the National Council on Medically Assisted Procreation (CNPMA, 2008) guidelines, clinical and laboratorial information were used after patients’ informed and written consent. All Authors disclose any actual or potential conflict of interest including any financial, personal or other relationships with other people or organizations within 3 years of beginning the submitted work that could inappropriately influence, or be perceived to influence their work, such as manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, laboratory supplies, and/or medical devices. It also includes employment, consultancies, stock ownership, honoraria, paid expert testimony, patent applications/registrations, and grants or other funding, including any financial arrangement with a company whose product is prominent in the submitted manuscript or with a company making a competing product, and any commercial affiliations.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
